data.title: The Queen Adelaide Saloon
data.meta_description:
On loan from York's (North Yorkshire, England) National Railway Museum, this is the Queen Adelaide (1792 to 1849) saloon, built in 1842. This is one of the earliest saloon coach and it resembles closely to the horse-drawn stagecoach of the period.
	
	In 1818, Princess Adelaide of Saxe-Meiningen married Prince William, a younger brother of King George IV.  When George died in 1830 (his only child Princess Charlotte had died at age 21 in 1817), William ascended to the throne, becoming King William IV, and Adelaide became Queen.
data.text:
On loan from York's (North Yorkshire, England) National Railway Museum, this is the Queen Adelaide (1792 to 1849) saloon, built in 1842. This is one of the earliest saloon coach and it resembles closely to the horse-drawn stagecoach of the period.

In 1818, Princess Adelaide of Saxe-Meiningen married Prince William, a younger brother of King George IV. When George died in 1830 (his only child Princess Charlotte had died at age 21 in 1817), William ascended to the throne, becoming King William IV, and Adelaide became Queen.
